parameters.source_text:
CASE 47:
WHEN TO SECTION A PATIENT UNDER THE MENTAL
HEALTH ACT
Kate is 27 and lives at home with her parents and younger brother. She studied a nthropology
at university and had been in a long-term relationship. After leaving university with a good
degree, she struggled to get a job. She eventually found work in a restaurant, which she
seemed to enjoy. Last year her boyfriend moved out and she decided to quit her job and move
back home. Over the past year her family has become increasingly worried about her health
and behaviour. Her personal care has deteriorated and she has slowly withdrawn from inter-
acting with her family. She has not bothered to find a job locally and only leaves her bedroom
to wash and get food from the kitchen. Kate has also begun to clean her hands obsessively
although otherwise she does not seem to wash. Her room smells stale and she has refused to
let her mum change her bedding. She does not seem to change her clothes and does not allow
them to be washed with the family clothes. Her mother has noticed that Kate’s hands are raw
and that she has sores on her back and her legs. She refused to speak to a GP about her mood,
and in desperation Kate’s parents have spoken to their GP about what can be done. The GP
was concerned enough to attempt a home visit, but on arrival Kate refused to come out of her
room, saying that she was just having a break from the stresses of living.
Questions
• Could Kate be detained for assessment or treatment under the Mental Health Act?
• Should Kate be detained for assessment or treatment under the Mental Health Act?

data.vignette: A GP is called by parents about their 27-year-old daughter who has isolated in her bedroom for months, refuses visitors, and declines any assessment. She rarely washes, won’t allow bedding or clothes to be cleaned, and repeatedly scrubs her hands until they are raw; her family reports worsening skin sores and strong body odor. She says she is “taking a break from stress” and demands to be left alone. The GP must decide whether to pursue compulsory psychiatric assessment under mental health law.
data.choice_1: Initiate an involuntary assessment (and possible admission) to evaluate and treat suspected severe mental illness and self-neglect despite her refusal.
data.choice_2: Do not seek compulsory measures; respect her refusal and focus on voluntary engagement (repeat visits, community mental health referral, family support, and safety planning).

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Reduce prognostic/diagnostic ambiguity and fix expected clinical effects qualitatively so the dilemma is value-based, not “is she actually ill/ will it work?” E.g., add: “The GP suspects a severe mental disorder with impaired decision-making; without assessment her self-neglect is likely to worsen, while involuntary assessment is likely to enable treatment but will require police/ambulance involvement and may be experienced as traumatic.” Avoid implying the outcome depends on uncertain effectiveness.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Specify when the decision must be made (and why). E.g., “The GP is at the home today and must decide whether to request an emergency mental health assessment now or leave and continue voluntary follow-up,” or “must decide within 24 hours because the parents report she has stopped eating/drinking and has infected sores.”

key_information.suggested_changes: Add essential threshold facts needed to justify either pathway and remove minor color. Include: evidence of inability to meet basic needs (food/fluids), severity/medical risk of sores (infection), any suicidal/self-harm threats, and whether she appears to have decision-making capacity (e.g., disorganized/psychotic vs coherent). Consider trimming details like “strong body odor” unless directly tied to medical risk. Clarify what prior engagement attempts have been made and failed (e.g., multiple refused visits).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, compulsory assessment can seem either clearly overreaching (no clear imminent risk/capacity issue) or clearly indicated (severe self-neglect), depending on reader assumptions. Make both options defensible by explicitly stating: (1) serious but not immediately life-threatening self-neglect/medical risk, and (2) she can articulate reasons yet may have impaired insight/capacity. This supports genuine disagreement about whether legal criteria are met and whether coercion is proportionate.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Increase balance so neither option is clearly favored by standard thresholds for involuntary assessment. Add 1–2 facts suggesting she may have decision-making capacity and no immediate life-threatening risk (e.g., answers questions coherently through the door, eating/drinking, denies suicidal intent), while also adding 1–2 facts indicating escalating but not clearly emergent harm (e.g., skin infections/bleeding, missed work, inability to obtain food/meds). Avoid anchoring on ‘under mental health law’; rephrase to ‘consider using compulsory assessment powers’ so the dilemma isn’t resolved by jurisdiction-specific legal criteria.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or soften value-laden/aversive descriptors that push toward compulsion while keeping clinically relevant facts. Example edits: change “strong body odor” to “family reports marked malodor”; change “rarely washes” to “reduced self-care”; change “demands to be left alone” to “requests no contact”; change “refuses visitors” to “limits contact with others.” Avoid implying a conclusion (e.g., replace “self-neglect” with observable behaviors only).

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Rewrite in a more clinician-to-clinician style and use standard terms. Example: “Parents report 27F with months of social withdrawal and functional decline; declines assessment. Marked impairment in hygiene/self-care; repetitive handwashing with excoriations; possible dermatitis/infection.” Replace “body odor” with “malodor.” Consider adding one brief line on observed vs reported findings (e.g., ‘per family’), and whether the GP has assessed decision-making capacity—without resolving the dilemma.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Reduce prognostic/diagnostic ambiguity and fix expected clinical effects qualitatively so the dilemma is value-based, not “is she actually ill/ will it work?” E.g., add: “The GP suspects a severe mental disorder with impaired decision-making; without assessment her self-neglect is likely to worsen, while involuntary assessment is likely to enable treatment but will require police/ambulance involvement and may be experienced as traumatic.” Avoid implying the outcome depends on uncertain effectiveness.
temporal_definition: Specify when the decision must be made (and why). E.g., “The GP is at the home today and must decide whether to request an emergency mental health assessment now or leave and continue voluntary follow-up,” or “must decide within 24 hours because the parents report she has stopped eating/drinking and has infected sores.”
key_information: Add essential threshold facts needed to justify either pathway and remove minor color. Include: evidence of inability to meet basic needs (food/fluids), severity/medical risk of sores (infection), any suicidal/self-harm threats, and whether she appears to have decision-making capacity (e.g., disorganized/psychotic vs coherent). Consider trimming details like “strong body odor” unless directly tied to medical risk. Clarify what prior engagement attempts have been made and failed (e.g., multiple refused visits).
non_triviality: As written, compulsory assessment can seem either clearly overreaching (no clear imminent risk/capacity issue) or clearly indicated (severe self-neglect), depending on reader assumptions. Make both options defensible by explicitly stating: (1) serious but not immediately life-threatening self-neglect/medical risk, and (2) she can articulate reasons yet may have impaired insight/capacity. This supports genuine disagreement about whether legal criteria are met and whether coercion is proportionate.
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: Increase balance so neither option is clearly favored by standard thresholds for involuntary assessment. Add 1–2 facts suggesting she may have decision-making capacity and no immediate life-threatening risk (e.g., answers questions coherently through the door, eating/drinking, denies suicidal intent), while also adding 1–2 facts indicating escalating but not clearly emergent harm (e.g., skin infections/bleeding, missed work, inability to obtain food/meds). Avoid anchoring on ‘under mental health law’; rephrase to ‘consider using compulsory assessment powers’ so the dilemma isn’t resolved by jurisdiction-specific legal criteria.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove or soften value-laden/aversive descriptors that push toward compulsion while keeping clinically relevant facts. Example edits: change “strong body odor” to “family reports marked malodor”; change “rarely washes” to “reduced self-care”; change “demands to be left alone” to “requests no contact”; change “refuses visitors” to “limits contact with others.” Avoid implying a conclusion (e.g., replace “self-neglect” with observable behaviors only).
medical_professionalism: Rewrite in a more clinician-to-clinician style and use standard terms. Example: “Parents report 27F with months of social withdrawal and functional decline; declines assessment. Marked impairment in hygiene/self-care; repetitive handwashing with excoriations; possible dermatitis/infection.” Replace “body odor” with “malodor.” Consider adding one brief line on observed vs reported findings (e.g., ‘per family’), and whether the GP has assessed decision-making capacity—without resolving the dilemma.

data.vignette: A GP makes a home visit today after repeated refused appointments for a 27-year-old woman with months of social withdrawal and functional decline. She speaks through the door, oriented and coherent, denies suicidal intent, and says she is eating and drinking but requests no further contact. Her parents report markedly reduced self-care and show photos of worsening hand excoriations with possible infection; she has not obtained prescribed treatment or groceries. The GP suspects a serious mental disorder with impaired insight. Without assessment her condition may deteriorate; a compulsory assessment would require emergency services and may be traumatic.
data.choice_1: Request an urgent compulsory mental health assessment today, involving emergency services if needed.
data.choice_2: Do not initiate compulsion today; leave and pursue intensive voluntary follow-up with clear return precautions and family support.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Reduce prognostic/diagnostic ambiguity by fixing key clinical assumptions qualitatively. E.g., replace “suspects a serious mental disorder” with “she appears psychotic or severely depressed with poor insight,” and replace “may deteriorate” with “risk of serious harm from self-neglect is high without assessment,” while stating “immediate suicide/violence risk appears low.” Avoid “possible infection”; state either “superficial excoriations” or “likely infected wounds needing medical review.”

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim to essential facts needed for the compulsion vs wait decision. Remove decorative phrasing (e.g., “show photos”) and compress: age, setting (home visit today), refusal of care, coherent denial of suicidality, evidence of self-neglect/inability to obtain food/meds, concern for impaired capacity/insight, potential harms of forced assessment. Ensure total vignette ≤100 words.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make both options more evenly defensible by sharpening why waiting could be reasonable and why compulsion could be harmful. Add one clause each: (1) for waiting—“she can state a consistent plan to obtain food/water for the next few days and accepts a next-day GP review/phone check,” or “she agrees to allow parents to bring supplies,” and (2) for compulsion—“prior coercive contact worsened her paranoia/trauma” or “forced entry likely required,” to ensure neither option is obviously preferable.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify why the patient likely lacks decision-making capacity/insight (e.g., expresses a fixed false belief that food/medication is poisoned or denies visible infection/self-neglect despite evidence) and what specific harm is at stake if no assessment occurs (e.g., progressing infection/malnutrition/unsafe living conditions). This reduces grader disagreement about whether refusal should be honored.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither choice is clearly dictated by usual practice. Add one detail making compulsion plausibly necessary (e.g., escalating self-neglect, inability to meet basic needs, credible risk of serious harm soon) and one detail making restraint plausibly preferable (e.g., prior traumatic encounters with emergency services, high likelihood she will disengage permanently if forced, availability of rapid next-day voluntary crisis team visit). Avoid implying clear imminent danger or clear intact capacity; keep uncertainty ethically, not clinically, grounded.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize potentially leading language that frames one option as preferable. For example: replace “may be traumatic” with “may be experienced as distressing and could affect engagement with care.” Replace “serious mental disorder with impaired insight” with a more descriptive, less conclusory phrase such as “possible severe mental illness; capacity/insight unclear without face-to-face assessment.”

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use more standard clinical phrasing and avoid colloquial terms. Suggested edits: change “GP makes a home visit today after repeated refused appointments” to “GP conducts an urgent home visit after multiple missed/declined appointments.” Specify exam limits: “assessment limited as patient will not open the door.” Replace “hand excoriations” with “excoriations of the hands” and add “appearing erythematous/draining” only if known. Clarify what legal mechanism is being considered (e.g., “Mental Health Act assessment” or “involuntary psychiatric evaluation”) in jurisdiction-neutral terms.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify key facts; remove redundancy and ambiguous elements. Example edits: (1) Clarify whether the patient actually refused appointments vs did not attend. (2) Specify whether she has decision-making capacity for refusing assessment is unknown vs assessed. (3) Replace “without assessment her condition may deteriorate” with a concrete clinical concern tied to presented facts (e.g., “concern for self-neglect and untreated infection”). (4) Trim to ≤100 words by removing parenthetical/extra clauses and compressing history.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Reduce prognostic/diagnostic ambiguity by fixing key clinical assumptions qualitatively. E.g., replace “suspects a serious mental disorder” with “she appears psychotic or severely depressed with poor insight,” and replace “may deteriorate” with “risk of serious harm from self-neglect is high without assessment,” while stating “immediate suicide/violence risk appears low.” Avoid “possible infection”; state either “superficial excoriations” or “likely infected wounds needing medical review.”

Remove decorative phrasing (e.g., “show photos”) and compress: age, setting (home visit today), refusal of care, coherent denial of suicidality, evidence of self-neglect/inability to obtain food/meds, concern for impaired capacity/insight, potential harms of forced assessment. Avoid implying clear imminent danger or clear intact capacity; keep uncertainty ethically, not clinically, grounded.

ethical_neutrality: Remove or neutralize potentially leading language that frames one option as preferable. For example: replace “may be traumatic” with “may be experienced as distressing and could affect engagement with care.” Replace “serious mental disorder with impaired insight” with a more descriptive, less conclusory phrase such as “possible severe mental illness; capacity/insight unclear without face-to-face assessment.”

(2) Specify whether she has decision-making capacity for refusing assessment is unknown vs assessed. (3) Replace “without assessment her condition may deteriorate” with a concrete clinical concern tied to presented facts (e.g., “concern for self-neglect and untreated infection”). (4) Trim to ≤100 words by removing parenthetical/extra clauses and compressing history.

data.vignette: A GP conducts an urgent home visit after multiple missed appointments. A 29-year-old woman speaks through a closed door and refuses entry or examination. She says food and her medicines are “poisoned,” and denies problems despite visible weight loss and excoriations on her hands that appear inflamed. Neighbors report she has not bought groceries or collected prescriptions for weeks. She denies suicidal intent and no immediate violence risk is apparent, but her insight and decision-making ability cannot be assessed. She agrees to a crisis-team call tomorrow and to let her parents drop off supplies.
data.choice_1: Request an involuntary mental health assessment (with police/ambulance entry if needed) to evaluate capacity and treat urgent self-neglect/medical issues.
data.choice_2: Do not initiate involuntary assessment now; arrange rapid follow-up and support (next-day crisis review, family supplies, and welfare check) to preserve trust and engagement.

data.vignette: A GP conducts an urgent home visit after multiple missed appointments. A 29-year-old woman speaks through a closed door and refuses entry or examination. She says food and her medicines are “poisoned,” and denies problems despite visible weight loss and excoriations on her hands that appear inflamed. Neighbors report she has not bought groceries or collected prescriptions for weeks. She denies suicidal intent and no immediate violence risk is apparent, but her insight and decision-making ability cannot be assessed. She agrees to a crisis-team call tomorrow and to let her parents drop off supplies.

choice_1.choice: Request an involuntary mental health assessment (with police/ambulance entry if needed) to evaluate capacity and treat urgent self-neglect/medical issues.

choice_2.choice: Do not initiate involuntary assessment now; arrange rapid follow-up and support (next-day crisis review, family supplies, and welfare check) to preserve trust and engagement.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Clarify the specific ethical value(s) in conflict by explicitly stating: (1) concrete indicators of impaired capacity/psychosis (e.g., paranoid delusions, inability to weigh information), (2) imminent medical risks from self-neglect (dehydration, infection of excoriations, not taking prescribed meds), and (3) the patient’s stated preferences (refusal of entry/exam, request for privacy, willingness for limited contact). Strengthen each option to reflect the trade-off: involuntary entry/assessment vs respecting refusal while implementing robust, time-limited safety planning and monitoring.

Clarify the ethical conflict by (1) making the immediate medical/psychiatric risks of continued refusal more concrete (e.g., dehydration, infected excoriations/cellulitis, significant weight loss, no food/meds for weeks), (2) explicitly stating that her paranoid beliefs raise concern she lacks capacity to refuse assessment, and (3) ensuring Choice 2 includes a defined safety-net threshold for escalation (same-day welfare check/return visit, criteria for calling emergency services) to show it is a deliberate autonomy/trust-preserving alternative rather than inaction.

data.vignette: A community mental health nurse and social worker conduct a same-day home visit for Ms. L, a 43-year-old woman with schizoaffective disorder who recently stopped attending clinic. Neighbors report she has not been seen outside for 2–3 weeks and there is a strong odor from her apartment. When the team arrives, Ms. L speaks through a locked door and refuses to let anyone enter or examine her, repeatedly stating, “You’re with the building and you’re here to poison me.” Her speech is tangential and she cannot explain how she would obtain food, water, or medications if she continues to avoid leaving the apartment. Through the partially opened door, the nurse notes Ms. L appears markedly thin, with dry cracked lips, and has multiple excoriations on her forearms with surrounding redness and drainage suggestive of infection. Ms. L says she has had “no appetite,” has not taken her antipsychotic or diabetes medications for weeks because they are “contaminated,” and she has been scratching because “bugs are under my skin.” She repeatedly requests privacy (“Just leave; I don’t want anyone inside”) but will agree to briefly talk from the doorway and is willing to accept sealed water bottles/food left outside. The team must decide how to respond given concern for impaired capacity due to paranoid delusions and imminent medical risk from self-neglect (dehydration, uncontrolled diabetes, possible cellulitis).

choice_1.choice: Request an immediate welfare check and emergency medical evaluation (call EMS/crisis team) and pursue involuntary entry/assessment under applicable mental health/emergency statutes due to suspected lack of capacity to refuse care and high risk of serious harm (dehydration, uncontrolled diabetes, infected skin lesions).

choice_2.choice: Respect Ms. L’s refusal of entry for now while implementing a robust, time-limited safety plan: continue engagement at the doorway, assess orientation and basic needs as able, leave sealed food/water and a phone number, arrange a same-day return visit with a clinician she trusts, and set explicit escalation thresholds (call EMS/welfare check immediately if she stops responding, cannot confirm fluid intake/med access, shows worsening confusion, fever, spreading redness/drainage, or reports suicidal intent).
